div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Legislative Council. ——The Legislative Council will hold a meeting on ‘Thursday next.
Quarantine. ——“Arrivals from Egyptian ports at Cyprus are subjected to medical inspection.
Council of Ministers. ——The Council of Ministers will assemble to-morrow at San Stephano under the presidency of Hussain Fakhri Pasha, Regent.

Murder of an English Fireman. ——The Italian and Greek ‘‘softeners,” accused of being concerned in the death of a fireman from an English merchant vessel, in Alex-Andria, are now in prison pending their trials.
Drowning Fatality. ——A native mason fell from the -ferry boat plying between Old Cairo and Gheimeh on Friday about 11 o’clock and was drowned. The body was recovered after an hour's search.

Dredger “ St. Giles.” —— The Admiralty dredger “St. Giles” which was for sometime engaged in the harbor works here has arrived at Alexandria from Devon-port. It was’ rumored here that the “St Giles” had come to grief on her voyage home, but she met with no misadventure.

Bahr e! Chazal. ——The Governor of Bahr el Ghazal no longer undertakes to arrange for the transport of parcels of Government employees in the Burh-el-Ghazal Province as heretofore. Government employees must make their own arrangements in this connection. ‘The Post and 'Telegraphs Department only accepts parcels addressed for delivery in Mishra, or in WA when the Jury River is open and notice has been given to hat to effect.

Fire at Omdurman. —— A fire broke out last week in two shops of the new Sirdar Street at Omdurman. ‘The policemen who arrived upon the scene found themselves unable to extinguish the fire as the only well in the neighborhood had no bucket. Mr. Kami, however, opened his house to them and invited ‘them to use his pumps which- helped: to extinguish the flames. Fortunately no one was injured and the damage done was not ‘considerable.

Carlo’s Collapsed House —— A further portion of, the house which collapsed in Sharia Mohamed Aly has fallen and three rooms fell through with a terrific crash on Friday. Suffocating dust arose and the tram service was stopped for about half an hour. A subscription list has been opened for the help of the sufferers and it is to be hoped that liberal support will be given to those poor. persons who have found themselves homeless.

Death by Drink. —— On Friday evening about 9 o'clock a Nero-peen was discovered on the pavement in a Cairo street in an advanced state of intoxicant-tin. On being conveyed to the caracul he muttered some words supposed to. have been in Italian. The officer on duty caused the man to be conveyed to the hospital, but he expired almost immediately on arrival there. The Italian Consulate has been advised of the occurrence in order to ascertain the man’s identity.

div.head: A BELATED ANNOUNCEMENT
div.p: Information regarding the trend of events in this country seems to travel very slowly to some parts. Of Europe, judging by a pa- trigraph, which appears in a recent issue of a Cologne newspaper. According to this journal “the idea is gaining ground in Egypt that the National Bank of Egypt must be transformed into a State bank. The large exporters of cotton will son require consider- rabble sums, and if these are not available at the right moment the whole of the pro- tits of the harvest will not be obtained, a matter which would have serious consequences- Wes to the economic life of Egypt. A State bank is needed, the Cologne newspaper sat- test, which would fundamentally support the export trade. in ‘cotton. That the suggestion is approved in high quarters is shown by the issue of a recent decree sanctioning the emission of shares by the National Bank of the nominal value of £500,000, and this, too, at a time when new foundations and a capital augmentations are regarded with skepticism.”

In view of the frequent references to the negotiations for the conversion of the National Bank into a State institution which have appeared in the “Gazette” and other journalist during the past twelve months the above announcement may not unreason- nobly he described as “late.”

div.head: BRIDGE-AT KHARTOUM.
div.p: Mr. MacNeil! asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether a bridge over the Nile at Khartoum was to be constructed at a cost of £250,000; whether a contract for the construction had yet been given to any and what firm; and, if not, whether it might be tendered for by open competition.
Sir E. Grey: I’ll make inquiries about this.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: Messrs. P. Henderson & Co’s. 8.8. “Irrawaddy” now in port, will sail on Wednesday. next for Dover, This fine steamer has still ascoma- (lotion for a few more passengers : fare £10-0-0.
The Papa Yanni liner “Arabian” arrived from Glasgow, Liverpool, Gibraltar, Tangiers and Malta with passengers and mails this morning.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA ARENOLITH COMPANY.
DURABILITY OF SAND BRICKS.
div.p: At this moment of crisis, which is attributed especially to speculation in land and in shares, the attention of the public has been attracted to the fact that Egypt lacks almost entirely an industry, which should also afford’a living for a certain proportion of the inhabitants of this country.

We have had occasion to note that there is among us an industry which is progressing and which gives not only employment to a suffciently large number of workmen, but will also give dividends to the capital which created it Invited by Mr. Schoeller, Chairman of the Company, we visited the works of the Alex- andria Arenolith Company situated on the bank of the Mahmoudieh Canal directly oppo- site the State Railways Nouzha station. This factory of Silicocalcareous bricks with its actual equipment ean produce about 50,000 bricks a day. Many of our readers will have noticed its chimney, 40 metres high, bearing in red letters the word Arenolith, which is to say sandstone.

For a long time this industry has been known in Europe, where these stones are used for the construction of the highest buildings, for they can resist a pressure of 200 kilogrammes, and even more, to the surface of one square centimétre ; i.e. they are three times stronger than the calcareous stone of Mex. ‘The system of manufacture, certain details of which are protected by patents, is simple enough. ‘The silicious sand is mixed by machines with chalk, and the mass so formed is raised by elevators to the presses where they are formed into bricks. On being taken from the presses the bricks are placed on waggons by which they are conveyed to the autoclaves. In these autoclaves, which are of large dimensions, each being able to hold 11,000 bricks at a time, they are exposed for a certain number of hours to steam under high pressure, which constitutes the hardening process. ‘The brick can be used immediately it leaves the hardening cylinders, and ‘it has the good quality of hardening still more under atmospheric influence.

The factory, which employs about 100 work- men, is situated very favourably on the right bank of the Mahmoudieh canal, and the State Railway line connects with that of the factory, so that orders for the interior can be despatch- ed either Ly rail or by water direct from the factory.

A high gas generating furnace in which the chalk will be caleinated is about to be built in the same factory on the most modern and most economical lines. In this way the company will be enabled to make bricks possessing all the qualities which a stone ought to have, to be used for solid constructions and without giving too great a weight to the building, This latter advantage i is of great value in Egypt, where one is often compelled to build on artificial soil.

In fact, the brick is stronger and lighter than the calcareous stone of the country and with its fine colour is especially adapted to a building with the appearance of masonry. The factory also makes variously shaped and coloured bricks with undestroyable colours with which one can obtain beautiful effects of architecture, and in the simplest manner.

One is convinced of this fact in observing the two handsome villas now being built at the Cleopatra Halte quite near the Ramleh tram line. But this stone is also already in use for more important ballings, and the Government Administrations employ it for many public buildings. Large offices have been built with this material at Gabbary station and the Government schools at Moharrem Bey are to be built with these bricks. The new Deaco- nesses’ Hospital will also be built of the same material and .it is being used for several private houses ori account of the rapidity and ease which it affords in construction.

Contractors who are, perhaps, not yet aware of the excellent qualities of the silico caleareous brick, called sandbrick in England, will be greatly interested to learn that “the new Liver- pool Cotton Bourse is built of this material. Alongside this bourse an immense building of seven storeys is also aboyt to be built of silico- ealeareous bricks, which proves what great confidence one has in this stone in Europe. In Prussia the Minister of Public Works has allowed their use for hydraulic constructions. In Holland, at the Hague, there have been entire streets made of this stone for ten years, the walls not being plastered. They have the aspect of having been built yesterday. Before the construction of the Arenolith Company's factory at Nouzha, Mr. Schoeller paid a visit to the Hague to assure himself of these tacts. In Spain and in Portugal, as well as in Italy, several factories of the same nature have been in operation for several years, and everywhere the Arenolith stone gives the greatest satis- faction.

The material is the best suited to the soil and the climate of Egypt. The factory is built in such a way that the production ean be doubled by adding some presses im- mediately the néed of them is felt, and we can only hope that this will soon be the case, and all the more so becanse the found- ers have never taken advantage of the cir- cumstances which raised immeasurably so many shares, knowing that their share in this solid concern, based upon ‘an industry which was a requirement of the country, must in time give a good account of itself.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL CAIRO.
div.p: Family Hotel. Built in 1904. Between Shepheard's Hotel and the Railway Station. Electric Light. Lift.
Sanitary arrangements up to-date. Open all the year round. Special terms for Government officials and Army of Occupation
NEW MANAGEMENT. 29242-26-11-90

div.head: PORTS AND LIGHTHOUSES ADMINISTRATION.
div.p: The case of Bimbashi Mohamed Safonat, Inspector of the Quays at Alexandria, whose official conduct was recently the subject of a Court of Enquiry, is now in the hands of the Parquet. This official’s subordinate, Amin, whose conduct was also the subject of investigation, will also be dealt with by the Parquet..

A Council of Disciplina met on Saturday. last at Port Said to enquire into the charges, against an official of this Administration, of, the name of Minarra. He recently resigned but withdrew his resignation and asked to be; tried by a Council of Discipline as-be con- siders he is not guilty of any official mis- conduct.

The Court of enquiry, which: has been sitting at Alexandria to enquire into the charges of bribery and other irregularities in the quay department of this administration, has found that bribery has been going on. The overhauling of this administration, consequent on the findings of the Court of enquiry, is expected to have an excellent result.
The announcement in the native Press that Bakry Bey would be transferred from Alexandria to Port-Said to replace Dixon Bey is incorrect.

Spiro Bey, Secretary General of the Ad- ministration, has been granted sick leave for two months from the 10th inst. Spiro Bey has already been on leave for some time past and asked for an extension on the grounds of ill health.

div.head: KHEDIVE'S INCOGNITO.
div.p: The Khedive has spent two days in Paris last week in the strictest incognito. He then left for Switzerland, and, according to the “Figaro,” intends to return to Paris in the course of the week to make an unofficial visit of some dura- tion. He will go, adds Reuter, to London before returning to Egypt.

div.head: LORD CROMERS GRANT.
div.p: Lord Cromer’s retirement pension is £900 per annum. No question can arise as to the procedure which the Government intend to adopt in regard to Lord Cromer’s grant, as, as we have already announced, the precedent which will be followed will be that of Sir Rowland Hill, who, on his retirement in 1864 was voted £20,000 as a token of the nation’s appreciation of his work for postal reform.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN COMMITTEE.
div.p: The dinner offered by the Parliamentary. Egyptian Committee on last night Friday night at the Metropole Hotel was very well attended, and went off splendidly, says the “Egyptian Standard.” Besides the delegates, the guests included several Members of Parliament, Professor Brown, Dr. Clark, Sir Thomas Barclay, Mr. Brailsford and others, The speakers, besides the chairman, Mr. J, M. Robertson, were Sheik Youssef and Hafiz Awad—who was granted a cordial reception— Professor Brown, Mr. Crabb, Dr. Rutherford, Dr. Clark and Sir Thomas Barclay. Exception made of Dr. Clark who was very outspoken and Sir Thomas Barclay who was apologetic for England, all the other speakers were studionsly moderate, emphasising Egypt’s friendliness to- wards England. ‘They also pointed out that Egypt does not claim the control of her finances or herforeign policy. She merely wants the gradual introduction of self-government, and the management of her own affairs at home. These sentiments were highly applauded.

div.head: THE VIVANTE MYSTERY.
div.p: The Alexandria Police have decided to eliminate all persons, who might be suspec- ted erroneously of being concerned in the Vivante mystery. With this purpose in view they have decided to enquire into the pre- sence of a young Italian, who happened to be in the hotel at the time of the murder. This man is not suspected of being concer- ned in the crime.

div.head: THE YEMEN TROUBLE.
SULTAN’S SPEECH TO NOTABLES.
div.p: On the occasion of the return to the Yemen of the deputation of representative Arabs who had come to Yildiz to discuss means of settling the troubles in the Yemen, the Sultan created a precedent by making a speech, in which he expressed his views of the situation. The speech was read at the farewell audience by the First Secretary, and stated that the Sultan was very grieved to learn that some of the population were rebellious, meriting extreme punishment, but not wishing bloodshed between Mussulmans he requested his hearers to return and ex- plain that bad conduct against the will of God and His prophet was punishable in this world and the next, and to declate the Sultan’s good feelings, his only desire being the happiness of his subjects. He had or- dered the Council of Ministers to prepare a list of reforms, which had now been sanctioned, assuring the prosperity of Yemen, regularity of justice and finance administration, and safety for life and property. The Arabs received decorations and were sent off on a special steamer.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit- within certain necessary limites- free discussion.

div.head: CAIRO WATER SUPPLY.
div.p: To THE EDITOR OF THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.”
Sir,—It is generally found that, after resid- ing some years in this country, we fall. into the ways of it and take things as they come.

So far, so good, ‘but I think where public health is concerned it is necessary to throw aside this indifference. When the artesian. wells at Rod el Forag were first started, I recollect a letter appearing at the time ‘in the “Cairo Morning News” froma Cairo: doctor, pointing out that certain injurious substances were found in this supply. Since that time, I have noticed that analyses have been made from time to time, probably at the instance of the Public Heath Department and»now. I notice that three experts are to be brought from Europe to again test this supply. . It will be rather interesting to know (1) why the ordinary native “Zeers” atter being used. to filter this water become black inside (2) why boilers show excessive scale (3) why’ the candles of a Berksfeld filter should also show signs of tutning black. Apart from what I have heard others say abont their boilers getting spoilt, I have proved it in a boiler used by myself. The PH.D. say it is not necessary to usea filter, when the supply is ‘from Rod el Farag ; but froin force of habit I ‘still continue to use mine, which is one of ten ‘candles and I found the above result. Last week you reported in your paper, that the \medical officer of the Egyptian Army had lodged a complaint with the Public Health Department regarding the quality of water. The health of cities depend to a great extent lon a pure water supply and I trust. that abler pens than mine will now take up the subject. ‘Meantime, enclosing my card and hoping yon ‘will find space to insert this.
Iam,
S. R.

div.head: PUBLIC SECURITY IN BEHERA.
div.p: Having been over 10 years in Behera, I took particular notice of the correspon- lence on the above subject, and although much against my grain to correspond, I am forced to do so owing to remarks made by “Interested.” “Interested” states there have been 9 murders since April. Does he mean in Damanhour or Behera? Althongh uninterested I know of 5 in the Markaz of Daman- hour, and 4in one night in Abou Homos, anda few days later 3 in one night in Teh-el-Barond, the last 7 only lately, not counting the native lady referred to; and I think you would find upon-enquiry that there were over 30, if not 50, murders within the time stated. Public security there is little or none now in Behera, and the Authorities are powerless to deal with or prevent the same, and will be until the magic wand of Egypt calls the corbash to be reinstated.
Yours Truly
10 Years Resident.

P.S. I forgot to post this in time for mail and since writing above, it maybe interest- ing and proof of my statements as regards the insecurity of Behera to inform you that the Commander of Police has been shot to-day at 8.0’clock while on duty near Kobour-el-Omara. On receipt of the above news the ‘mudir, snb-inudir, and sanitary doctor, left by special train (Delta) to make enquiry. Doubtless you will have news of this latest outrage by telegraph.
10 Years Resident.

Our Damanhour correspondent writes : — On the night of the 27th inst., while the commandant of the Behera police was at Kom Hamada markaz, he was informed that a gang of highway robbers had met of:party of travellers near Haddein ayd after shooting at them had seized five of their camels. The commandant immediately set off with a small party in search of the raiders, and, striking the camel track they followed this until they came up with two of them. A forcible resistance was offered by the meranders and. shots were exchanged. ‘he commandant received. three rounds, two in the breast and ther in the right arm. Only one arrest was effect. Every hope is entertained that’ the commandant will recover from his wounds.

div.head: POLICE INSUBORDINATION.
div.p: In its issue of this morning the “Egyptian Standard” remarks :—

“An extraordinary story of official tyranny reaches us coneerning a police officer of ‘I'‘annub an outpost in the district of Tala, named Mohammed Kamal. This ‘officer was recently transferred from Lower Egypt to Jebel district in Assuan province, which is considered to be in itself a punishment. He has accordingly sent in his resignation which has been accepted by the authorities. The cause alleged for inflicting this punishment on the officer in question was that he was discovered to be one of the signatories to the Denshawai petition. We know the reactionary interpretation of discipline which makes official independence’ crime, but we may ask if the same officer had signed one of the ganegyrics of Lord Cromer he would have been punished in any way.”

Whatever the facts of the case may be surely even our irrational contemporary ‘The Egypt Standard” could not seriously expect such an act of insubordination to be overlooked? Moreover we fail to see the parallel which our worthy confrére draws.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN ESTATES,
THE CHAIRMAN’S SPHECH.
REASSURING EFFECT.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Monday.

At the general meeting of the Egyptian Estates the chairman’s speech had a reassuring effect. He accentuated the fact that the crisis. was purely financial and that the wealth of the. country was unaffected. The company’s pre-perties showed large increases on ‘cost value. Their agricultural estates alone, when developed, would more than cover the capital debentures. Mr. Lang Anderson confirmed this and stated that their town properties were also thoroughly sound ‘investments. The chairman stated that Mr. Montague Summers. had left for Egypt by ‘Friday’s mail service and he is therefore due at Port Said on Wednesday.

div.head: EGYPT'S WATER SUPPLY.
THE EXPERT COMMITTEE.
div.p: The Metropolitan “Water Board pronented an emergency report on the 19th inst., which it was stated that a communication ‘had | been received from the Egyptian Government, stating that it was proposed to appoint English, French and German experts to report on the | water supply of that country. The Council of the Royal Society had been approached, and had recommended that Dr. Houston, the Board’s bacteriologist and chief water examiner, should be selected. The Committee had come. to the unanimons conclusion that Dr. Houston should. be permitted to attend the Conference, which would be held in November next. The fee would be £750. The Committee recommended that Dr. Houston should be permitted to receive the fee.

Mr. King pointed out that that afternoon they had voted, without discussion, in favour of Dr. Houston receiving £400 for work done for the Belfast Corporation, and the question was where this was going to end.
The chairman said Dr. Houston proposed to take his vacation at the time named.
After further discussion, the recommeéndation was adopted by 18 votes to 13.

div.head: MAN v. LION.
A FIERCE FIGHT.
div.p: The “Sudan Times” gives the following account of a fierce fight between a Government engineer and a wounded lion, in which, happily the lion came off second best, though ‘worsted by the timely arrival of the crew of the ship, of which Mx Salmon, the lion hunter was engineer : —

Severely wounded and bruised as the result of an encounter with a lion, Mr. C. H. Salmon, one of the engineers of the Steamers and Boats Department, arrived on board the steamer “Dal” at Khartoum North last Friday evening.
A correspondent at Khartoum North writes us the following narrative of the incident as related to him by eye-witnesses:

Abont eight days ago Mr. Salmon while on board the Steamer ‘Metemmah” between Fashoda and Melut, discovered a lion among the bushes on the shore. He at once armed himself and disembarked and started for him, asking those on board not to follow him. He shot twice at the lion, both shots taking effect. One bullet struck him in the shoulder and the other in the abdomen. After a struggle of a few minutes, which seemed to be his death agony, the lion lay motionless. ‘But upon Mr. Salmon’s approaching, the lien bounced upon him throwing him down to the ground, and crouching upon him. Notwithstanding the critical posi- tion in which he was, however, Mr. Salmon did not lose his presence of mind. He held the lion’s neck with bis left hand and was fumbling with his right for his knife. Before he succeed- ed in finding the knife, the lion had bitten his thigh and crushed his ‘toes. He gave the beast a stab in the eyes which infu- riated him, and he snapped at the hand that struck him, badly lacerating and sinashing it. The pain, however, was too much for him, and ‘he started to retreat. The crew of the steamer now arrived upon the scene. They despatched the exhausted lion without much difficulty, and earried Mr. Salmon to the boat. The barges which were towed by the steamer were left at that place, and the steamer sailed with all possible speed to Fashoda, where Mr. Salmon was taken to the hospital, and received medical attention. He was then transferred to the steam- er “Dal,” on board of which be was brought to Khartoum, accompanied by Sagh Mohd. Effendi Burhan, M.D.
The lion is one of the biggest of its kind, as evidenced by its skin, which our correspondent saw on board the “Dal.”

div.head: EGYPTIAN CONSTRUCTIONS LTD.
div.p: We are given to understand that the Grant, Bondi and Chinn Branch of Egyptian Constractions Limited have been given the sanitary and hot water installation and cold water supply, inclusive of the drainage scheme of the new reformatory at Ghizeh, for the Prisons Department of the Ministry of the Interior, the value of the contract being about £10,000. The only two firms competent to tender for this work were Messrs. Grant, Bondi and Chinn of Oairo and Messrs. Jennings of London. We may mention that this in the most important work in sanitation going on in Egypt at the present time.

div.head: CRICKET.
ALEXANDRIA v. CAIRO STAFF & DEPTS.
div.p: A cricket match was played on the Alexandria ground on Saturday afternoon between the Alexandria Cricket Club and the Cairo Staff and Depts., resulting in an easy win for the former. The notable feature of the match was the excellent batting of Mainprice for Alexandria, who gained a complete mastery over the ball and just topped the century by _ pretty and faultless play. A useful contribution of 42 not out was also made by McLean, who drove with considerable force, and 8. R. Carver, who had 58 to ‘his credit, also gave an ex- CellNet exhibition of hard hitting. Prosser, H. B. Carver, and Barnard were responsible for the dismissal of the Cairo team for 125 runs, the first named taking 3 wickets for 29 runs, the second 2 for 42, and the third 3 for 19. For the Staff and Depts. Jordan dismissed six of the Alexandria team and gave far more trouble than any of the bowlers, bent when Mainprice had broken the backbone of the bowling the others players indulged in slogging and ran not a few risks. div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO
div.p: Un succeeds aprés l’autre. La terrasse du Casino était de nouveau comble pour les concerts d’hier, le matin comme |’aprésmidi. Il n’y a en effet rien de mieux pour passer une journée trés agréablement. Concert, chanteurs et cinématographe, tout était parfait. Le grand festival Wagner est donc fixé pour dimanche prochain a 11 heures du matin.

div.head: Municipalite d’Alexandrie
AVIS
div.p: Le 2 aoit 1907 de9h. am. a 1h. p.m. la Municipalité procédera a la vente aux enchéres publiques prés du Fort Sud (Porte Rosette) d’une quantité de 10.000 m3 environ de pierre provenant de la dite démoli- tion, ainsi que d’une quantité de fenétres, portes et bois vieux. Les pierres sont divisées en lots de 20 4 100m3. Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d’enchére de 1% et ' déposer le 10% de la valeur de la marchandise achetée au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement intégral 4 la Caisse Municipale le lendemain du jour del’adjudication. Ils auront 4 supporter les droits de carritre au profit de la Ville et devront enlever les pierres achetées dans un délai de (10) dix jours sous peine de folle enchére pour compte de l’adjudicataire et sous perte du dépdt de 10 %. La Municipalité est librede ne pas donner ‘suite & adjudication, quels que soient les prix offerts. Alexandrie le 26 Juillet. 1907.
L’Administrateur
30699-3-1 (signé) W. P. Cuataway

div.head: La Societe Egyptionne de la Daira Sanieh.
div.p: Il est porté a la connaissance des intéressés qu’un dividende intérimaire de £ 1 Sh. 5 par action ordinaire et de £10 par part de fonda- teur (deferred shares) sera payé & partir du ler Aott 1907 aux guichets de la National Bank of Egypt, au Caire, 4 Alexandrie et 4 Londres’ contre remise du coupon N° 4 pour les actions ordinaires et du coupon N° 3 pour les _ parts de fondateur (deferred shares). (Le paiement 4 Londres se fera sous déduction de l’income tax).
Le Caire, le 19 Juillet 1907.
Le Président du Conseil d Administration.
(Signé) Harakr.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujour@ hui @ 11h, 1/2 am).

Le marché. n’a pas présenté ce matin la méme animation que vendredi dernier et la cote a été moins soutenue pour les valeurs dirigeantes, mais la tendance, s'il faut en croire la généralité des intéressés, -demeure ferme avec unedemande de bon augure pour l’avenir. Il y a des acheteurs, dit-on, et en général ils doivent payer un prix supérieur & celui coté. Bref, les acheteurs affluent, tandis que les ven- deurs se sont éclipsés. Nous avons déjA signalé trop de fois les raisons qui déterminent ces revirements haussiers chaque fin de mois pour y revenir.

Les affaires ont porté spécialement sur Agricole, qui a cloturé offerte 4 7 7/8 et sur la National Bank qui a perdu 1/4 de livre & 19 3/16. La Daira Sanieh a, an contraire, gagné 1/4 de livre 4 14 1/8 et. PObligation Crédit Foncier 5 fr. l’ancienne 4 306 et 8 fr. 50 la nouvelle 4 264 1/2. La Delta Light a été inscrite A 9 1/2 ex coupon.

En ce qui concerne |’Obligation Crédit Fon- cier, la hausse ininterrompue dont ce titre bénéficie depuis quelques jours serait occa} sionnée, sil faut en croire un bruit acerédité en bourse, & un découvert qu’on cherche a égorger. Si ce bruit est fondé, il est probable que le recul,constaté récemment sera totale- ment regagné, et au-deld.

Une autre valeur qui progresse de fagon inattendue, aprés de longs mois de baisse et de marasme, c’est la Building Lands dont le prix remonte d’un coup de 2 1/16 & 2 7/16-1/2. La raison qu’on allégue pour cette reprisa soudaine est le rachat par la société elle-méme de ses titres dépréciés, |
En hausse encore les Tramways d’Alexan- drie de 136 4 137 les Privilégiées et de 280 i 282 les Dividendes, |’Alexandria Water de 10 5/8 & 10 3/4, la Land Bank de 6 13/16 a 7 1/16.

Parmiles petites valeurs la Delta Land, trés soutenue, s’avance de 1 7/16 4 1 1/2, Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 20/9 4 21, PAnglo-Egyptian Allotment de 1 7/8 4 2 l’action et de 50 4 60 P.T. la part de fondateur, les Cotton Ginners de 11/4 41 5/16, et la Levico de 1/4 a 5/16. En revanche, les Nungovich Hotels revien- nent de 14 4 13, l’action nouvelle Comptoir de 25/164 21/4, Union Fonciére de 4 1/2 a 4 7/16, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 4 1/16 a 4.
Les Estates sont trés sontenus A 1/2-9/16. La Cassa di Sconto reprend: de 25 & 26.
Le reste de la cote demeure sans changement.

Ainsi que nous l’avons déja dit au début de ce bulletin, bien que l’ensemble dela cote ne soit pas aussi satisfaisant que vendredi der- nier, l’impression générale est meilleure. Les acheteurs ne s’esquivent pas de facon aussi absolue que naguére et si pour certains titres, comme la National Bank, ‘les transactions ne s’effectuent qu’au prix d’une réduction, pour d’autres, au contraire, les acquéreurs acceptent de payer un surplus.
Le tout est desavoirs’il nes’agit pas d’un simple découvert ou d’une réaction passa- gére, ou si p aIIHOEREON est appelde & ce consolider.

div.head: HAUGUE CONFERENCE
ABOLITION OF CONTRABAND
DIVERGENCE OF OPINION
div.p: The Hague, July 27.

The Conference debated the British proposal regarding the abolition of contraband, which was opposed by France, Russia, United States, aid Germany, who urged the framing ofa list of contraband articles. Lord Reay express- ed surprise at the attitude of the United States, quoting American state documents showing that the United States, formerly urged the abolition of contraband. Lord Reay declared that it was impossible to separate absolute contraband from relative. General Porter, replying-to Lord Reay, said that he preferred the modern policy of President Roosevelt to the ancient and out-of-date poliey quoted by Lord Reay. ( Reuter)

div.head: ROYAL IRISH CONSTABULARY
div.p: A MUTINOUS MEETING.

Brirast, July 28. 500 men of the Royal Irish Constabulary at an excitéd meeting in the barrack square resolved to demand a _permanent increase in .pay of a shilling a day, an increase in pensions, and the right to discuss grievan- ces whenever they please. Crowds of cheer- ing towns people invaded the barracks and earried the ringleader on sheir shoul- ders to the Custom House where he harangued the crowd, amid the cheers of the populace, including the strikers, (Aeuter)

div.head: RAISULI AND MACLEAN.
div.p: IMPERIAL TROOPS ACTIVE.
TANGIER, July 27.
The Imperial troops have attacked the Pretender’s position at Marchica and have been repulsed with heavy loss. (Reuter)
TANGIER, July 27.
The Sultan’s forces have arrived on the horders of the Khmass country where El Raisuli is detained. (Reuter)
TANGIER, July 28.
The Snltan’s forces have attacked the Kimass border villages. They have gained a complete victory, killing many people and burning and looting the villages. (Reuter)

div.p: PROTEST AGAINST REPATRIATION.
JOHANNESBURG, July 27,
The Chinese in a number of Rand Mines have petitioned against repatriation, pointing out that their contracts entitle them to a renewal of them. (Reuter)

div.p: BOTH BADLY DAMAGED.
London, July 27.
The destroyers “Waveney” and “Rother” have been damaged during the night, in a collision off Beachy Head, in connection with the mobilization manoenvres. (Reuter)

Kent beat Leicesterhire by 21 runs. Notts beat Middlesex by 13 runs. Gloucestershire beat Warwickshire by 7 wickets. Surrey beat Hampshire by 5 wickets. (Reuter)

div.head: THE KOREAN SITUIATION.
DISBANDMENT OF ARMY.
ANNEXATION UNNECESSARY.
div.p: —Seovr, July 28.

Marquis Ito’s plan involves the disbandment of the Korean army, substituting an equal number of Japanese troops. Marquis Ito, in an interview granted to a representative of the Associated. Press, said that the new Convention dispelled the idea that Japan was gradually annexing Korea, which was unnecessary. (Reuter)

div.p: RECOVERED NEAR BALEARICS.
Madrip, July 27.
A balloon, with military engineers, has been blown out to sea and has disappeared. This is the fourth accident of the kind in Europe within a few weeks.
(Later). The balloonists have been picked up northward of the Balearics. (Reuter)

div.p: COLLISION WITH TROOPS.
Raon L’Eraps, July 28.

The bootmakers on strike were attacked by the gendarmerie and the troops. One striker was killed, another is «dying, and 10 are wounded. The Captain of Police has been seriously wounded and two officers of the Chasseurs, 11 police and Chassenrs more slightly. (Havas)

The Russo-Japanese commercial and shipping agreement and fishery convention have been signed. (Reuter)

The 15th August will be celebrated at Tirnovo by grand fétes, it being the 20th anniversary of the accession of Prince Ferdinand. (Havas)

At the elections of the General councils the republicans of the left and the radical socialists headed the polls. (Havas)

Prince Borghese as arrived here and has proceeded to Moscow. (Reuter)

Prince Borghese has arrived at the head of the competitors in the Pekin-Patis motor car race. (Havas)

Prince Borghese has arrived. (Reuter)

Prince Borghese has taken 47 days to covet the distance, between Peking and Moscow. He is now being feted by the Italian colony.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN FINDS.
div.p: SAYINGS OF CHRIST.

Theological students attach great importance to the recently discovered Coptic writings which have been acquired by M. Rustafjaell, so far as the “Sayings of Jesus” are concerned. Not that they throw much fresh light upon the life or personality of Our Lord, but they suggest new readings of certain passages in the canonical Scriptures. or the Apoorypha. There is also a certain mysticism in some of the sayings that is not altogether inconsistent with the known sayings of Jesus, but that is more marked than in the narratives of the four evangelists. Thus Our Lord is represented as saying : “The Kingdom of Heaven is within you, and whoever shall know himself shall find it” and “Everything that is not before thy face and that which is hidden from thee shall be recalled to thee, for there is nothing hidden which shall not be made manifest nor buried. which shall not be raised.” Other instances might be given. And there are cases in which familiar passages are given in a slightly different version, as, for instance : “Jesus saith, A prophet is not acceptable in his own country, neither doth a physician work cures upon them that know him.”

As regards the other manuscripts and relics which M. Rustafjaell is said to have acquired, only experts will be able to appraise their value. The’ discovery of Egyptian antiquities is going on at an ever-increasing pace and what would have seemed wonderful even twenty or thirty years ago would not necessarily strike the learned in that way at the present time.

“It is now admitted,” said one gentleman whose name is well known in connexion with. the study of Egyptian and early Christian antiquities, “that the bulk of the manuscripts belong to the ninth, tenth, and eleventh centuries, only about a dozen rolls dating so far back as the sixth century. Well, the sixth century was as far removed, from the time of Christ as, say, the reign of King Henry IV. is from our day. Therefore any version of the ‘sayings of Jesus’ of the sixth century, sup- posing that to be the date, although this is not explicitly stated, obviously could not be of first- rate authority.. The manuscripts discovered by Drs, Grenfell and Hunt, of the Egypt Exploration Fund, dated from the ‘second’ century, to which period many authorities assign the ‘books of the New Testament. These were. dis- covered at Oxyrhyncus, one of the chief cities of ancient Egypt, about 190 miles south of Cairo. There were two important finds here— the first in 1897, the second in 1903. You will remember what a stir was made by the discovery of these literary treasures.”

A representative of ‘The Tribune” called at the British and Foreign Bible Society yesterday and saw Mr. I’. Herbert Darlow, who said: “It does not follow that even if the manuscripts are of the tenth or eleventh century they are unimportant, since they may really be, as is claimed, translations of early Greek works which have disappeared. This, however, remains to be seen. Gentlemen who discover or acquire ancient documents are very apt to exaggerate their importance.

“There is no doubt that the fragments of the ‘Logia’ discovered by Professor Grenfell and his colleague of the Egypt Exploration Fund will add to our knowledge. Biblical stu- dents, indeed, are greatly indebted to the researches of the Egyptologists. They have unearthed many documents written in the very same Greek that was used by the writers of the Scriptures—not the Greek of classic times, but the Greek of everyday life in the time in which the New Testament was written.”

The Right .Rev. Abbot Gasquet, as a representative Catholic, was next consulted on the subject, and he said that so many discoveries had been put forward that he did not care to express any opinion about the latest one. “It will be necessary,” he said, “for the actual documents to be inspected by competent scholars and subjected to their criticism,

div.head: THE LAMBERT AFFAIR.
div.p: The Daily Telegraph's Paris correspondent thus comments on the article. of ‘Le Temps” which was summarised in our last issue

If I return ‘to ‘this’ article it is the simple reason that it has brought to the front question ag to which no misunderstanding ought to prevail. The article is much sharper in tone than those on foreign matters usually appearing in our very: moderate contemporary, and it is this very asperity which has created the little sensation to which I allude. But the relations between the two countries and their Governments are so very friendly that the bitterness thus displayed ‘may fairly be regarded as the exception which proves. the role. If these relations had not been so cordial there would probably have been leas plain-speaking. The point, however, which has to be made clear, and which is at the bottom of the argument developed throughout by the writer, is that neither’ the French Government nor the people which it represent considers that France has waived any of the traditional rights and privileges which-she held in Egypt before the beneficent entente cordiale, was concluded. Some: little time ago, owing to some remarks in an Egyptian newspaper as to England’s position on the banks of the Nile, and as to the expediency, from. her point of view, of converting the occupation. into a protectorate, I went thoroughly into this question, and ascertained from: the most competent authorities that such a course would not -meet. with ready acquiescence in France, The, capitulations and the very rights and claims mentioned by the writer in the “Temps” last- evening were appealed to as showing that even so far as France was concerned, long and laborious negotiations would have to be entered upon, and then they might not end as England desired, while, from various other quarters,-and, notably, from the Sultan of Turkey, the strongest opposition might be anticipated.

The moral of all this is that it would be the greatest: mistake to assume that in the agreement of 1904 France has given England a free hand, so far as she herself is concerned, in Egypt. She has done nothing. of the sort. With the exception of the renunciation of an anti- English policy, and the various points expressly set forth in» this agreement, the relative positions of the two countries on the banks of the Nile remain unchanged. Scrupulous attention to. this fact is necessary, as it will prevent one of these unfortunate misunderstandings which are sometimes attended with ‘mischievous results. The article in the “Temps” is a direct warning, that France intends to hold to her rights and privileges in Egypt, and that she will insist, if necessary, on their being respected. I have drawn your attention more than once to the special interest manifested here’ in the Egyptian Nationalist movement, and this: would assuredly not be the case if France considered that she had. practically relinquished her position in the Khedive’s dominions.

All this is well worth noting, since, as have explained, acquaintance with French views : can avert those little jars to which oversight or ignorance of those opinions might lead. French political opposition to England in Egypt has died out, and France pays full ‘tribute to England for the staunch support which’ she has received from. her in all the phases of the Moroccan question. The entente cordiale is working thoroughly well. By pointing out any particular matter which might create an erroneous impression as to British feeling and aims, the cause of this auspicious entente is really best served. And the main point to be borne in mind is that France is now desirous, as she formerly was, for the preservation of her special interests and rights in Egypt.
The “Journal de: ‘Genéve” says :—

Nous savons quant 4 nous que tout n’allait pas pour le mieux dans l’Ecole di- rigée par M. Lambert. Il: n’y pouvait rien et son successeur n’y pourra sans doute pas grand’chose de plus. La propagande du parti dit de la Jeune Egypte, en insurrection ouverte contre ’administration anglaise, a beaucoup modifié lesprit des étudiants. Ils n’apportent depuis quelque temps 4 leurs études que de I indifférence. Le droit les intéresse beaucoup moins que la politique. Rien n’est amusant acet Age comme de sé croire voué A une grande tAche révolution- naire. Bruyants, indisciplinés, ‘ paresseux, ils font le désespoir de leurs mattres.

Peut étre M. Dunlop a-t-il rendu respon- sable de cet état de‘choses, M. Lambert, tandis que les Mnstapha Kamel et autres agitateurs que seule la jeunesse inconsciente des villes égyptiennes peut prendre au sérieux en sont seuls coupables. Peut-étre espére-t-il qu’un Anglais fera: mieux com- prendre qu'un Francais, aux étudiants en droit la différence qui existe entre l’Egypte réformée par Vadministration anglaise et . ’Egypte des Ismail et des Tewfik. Il est ‘ peu probable que M. Lambert qni est un - homme de valeur et. de grand bon sens, . ait laissé soutenir & l’école une thése con- traire. Mais l’agitation superficielle des fel- lahs en jaquette, qui jouissent au Caire d’une prospérité due 4 ’Angleterre, ne se laisse pas raisonner. Peut-étre alors M. Dunlop veut-il étre le maitre d’imposer la discipline en contrélant de plus prés Vattitude dee étudiants.

Eotre la France et ’Angleterre cette petite question ne peut rien gfter. Si cependant elle faisait naitre quelque aigreur, Angleterre aurait beau jeu de répondre a la France qu’elle s’étonne de la” voir si at- tachée & ses écoles d’Orient au moment ot elle repasse si volontiers 4 l'Italie celles qui ont pour seul tort d’étre sous une direction religieuse.

div.head: LORD ROSSLYN RIVORCED.
HIS VISIT TO CARIO.
div.p: LORD ROSSLYN DIVORCED.
HIS VISIT TO CAIRO.

The action tor divorce. brought against the Rarl of Rosslyn by. the Rt. Hon. Georgiana Robinson, or St. Clair-Erskine, Countess of Rosslyn, came before Lord Mackenzie in the} yon of Session, Bdinburgh, last Saturday week

Petitioner, who was the first witness, said she was married to Lord Rosslyn at St. Mark’s Jhurch, London, on March 20, 1905. After a four abroad, she and her husband settled down at her house, 11, Norfolk- -atreet, Park- ane. Subsequently they. were in various places, both in Scotland and abroad.
Counsel (for the petitioner): Is it the case that in 1906 differences arose between your husband and yourself, of which he was responsible—It is.
There was a separation, and thereafter you nade things up and lived together again at nis request 1— Yes.
Do, you remember going in July, 1906, on a yachting eruise,.and arriving at Trou- ville?—I do.
‘Do you remember Lord Rosslyn bringing 2 lady on board?—I do.
He gave her the. name of Mrs. Saunders?— He did.
You did not know her before?—No.
You were somewhat surprised ‘at’ the de- meanour of Lord Rosslyn and this lady*—I was very much indeed.
Is it the case that after dinner your husband took this lady ashore?—It is.
When did he return?—He returned the next morning, at half-past eight.
Did he give you a satisfactory explanation ?—He did not.

Did you leave the yachtt—I left at once with my sister and my nephew. Since then I have not lived with my husband. I had various inquiries made as to who this lady was, and as to my husband’s movements. As the result of these inquiries. in Paris. and: slsewhete proceedings were taken in the English courts for divorce, but as I ascertained on legal advice that my husband’s domicile was -in Scotland, the present action was. raised and the English proceedings withdrawn.
This closed Lady Rosslyn’s evidence.

Madame Coppenowle, of the hotel at & Rue Picot, Paris, gave her. evidence” through an interpreter. She. stated : that- Mrs. Muriel, Saunders lived at’8, Rue Picot. and that she remembered Lord Rosalyn: coming to Rue Picot.
Lady Rosslyn was then requested to stand . and the witness was asked if she was the lady called Mrs. Saunders.
Witness “replied in the negative. Lady Rosslyn then left the court-room.
Counsel: Was Mrs. Saunders living at Rue Picot when ford Rosalyn came to stay there?—Yes,
When did he’ come there 1—About Oct.- 18, 1906.
How ‘long, did he continue: to reside at 8, Picot, alter that time 7—Until Dec. 12.
Replying to further questions, witness. said that Lord Rosslyn and. Mrs. Saunders some time after left. f for Cairo, and returned on April 20 to Rue Picot, living. there, until June18.
Mr. Macphail: (counsel for the Countess) was raked the judge if Lord Rosslyn was in England and be replied that. he believed he was abroad.

Jean Coppenowle, husband of the pees witness, said he was also emploed in’ the hotel, 8, Rue Picot. He knew y Mrs. Mariel Saunders, who lived. there, and -he remembered Lord Rosslyn coming g ‘there to stay last October.

M. Cintrad said he was a private inquiry agent, and had been instructed to keep a watch on Lord Rosslyn at Rue Picot. On May 22 last, in company with Mr. Fabaran, a solicitor’s clerk from London, he saw Lord "Rosslyn Shown a photograph, witness identified it as that of Lord Rosslyn. He saw Lord Rosslyn and Mrs. Saunders drive in a motor-car to a race meeting and return to Rue Picot.
A solicitor carrying on business in London said he acted for Lady Rosslyn.
Have you seen the lady that Lord Rosslyn is going about Paris with” under the name of Mrs. Saunders !—I have.
She is not Lady Rosslyn ?1—No.
A decree of divorce was then pronounced.

div.head: TOLD BY A MOTHER.
div.p: 11, Albion Street,
Rugeley, England.

From childhood I have had kidney and bladder trouble, but since my marriage (over 7 years ago), I have suffered more than I can tell, especially during pregnancy. For the few months preceding the birth of my children, the water collected in my limbs and body, making in a dreadful size, I became so big that I had to go sideways up and down stairs ; my legs were swollen as large as buckets, and I must have weighed over 18: stone. I used to be afraid that, if the water reached my heart, I should be gone.
I suffered from violent cutting pains in the back and loins ; I would be nearly blind with pains in the head, and my heart seemed as though it would leap into my. mouth. I was a walking misery.
The doctor described my illness as dropsy, but his medicine did me no lasting good.
Of Doan’s Backache Kidney Pills however, I cannot speak too highly; they have made me 4 different woman, and if married women knew what. a blessing these pills are, they would never be without them.

After I had used Doan’s Pills a few days, they began to flush out great quantities of water, and as the water was the swellings gradually went down. that was not all; I never suffer as I used to from the terrible backaches, pains in the head,. or heart trouble.
I don’t know when I felt so well as I do now.
(Signed) Marton TYLER.
Doan’s Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at 18 P,T. per box,

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
